jokes.joke: Suzy Izzard: Imagine if missiles had feelings. One day, a missile zips through the air, glancing down at a sign in Palestine Square that’s displaying targets in the Gush Dan area and thinks, “Really? This ‘rain’ or whatever they call it? I was aiming for a tranquil retirement in a small, cozy area, perhaps near a Mediterranean beach, not plastered on some drab target sign!” Meanwhile, over in Tehran, the Iranian Foreign Minister is addressing the clearly confused missiles, telling them, “Military deployment doesn’t scare us!” as if missiles are terrified of unsightly military uniforms or the awkwardness of team meetings. Picture them buzzing like anxious interns at a company retreat, not sure whether to seize the day or file for a ceasefire at HR after a botched prank on a Wizz Air flight—where fighter jets showed up not for an existential threat, but because a couple of passengers mistook turbulence for a thriller plot twist! Ah, the modern narrative of conflict, it's like trying to make sense of an action movie script written by a committee of clowns and philosophers!

Lewis Black: So, let me get this straight—Wizz Air had to scramble fighter jets because someone pulled a prank on a flight! A PRANK! I mean, when did flying become more hazardous than a game of charades? You’ve got missiles raining down in Palestine, and we’re panicking about a guy who made a joke about the peanuts being stale! And here I thought the only thing that could hijack a plane was an actual hijacker! What’s next, a game of tag at 30,000 feet? Welcome to the new world order, where the biggest threat isn't terrorism, but a guy pretending to steal the last bag of chips!

**Jerry Seinfeld**: So, the commander of the Iranian Air and Space Force says that if the enemy makes a mistake, they’re going to respond stronger than ever. I can’t help but wonder, what kind of mistakes are we talking about here? I mean, is it like forgetting someone’s birthday or accidentally sending a text to the wrong group chat? Because nothing says “beef” like a misplaced emoji. "Oops! Was that a picture of my lunch and not a warhead? My bad! Now I'm sending an airstrike instead of just a slice of birthday cake!"

**Jerry Seinfeld:** Isn’t it funny how politicians win elections by positioning themselves as tough guys? It’s like we're just waiting for the Prime Minister of Japan to show up to the parliament with a leather jacket and sunglasses, saying, “I don’t negotiate, I dominate!” I mean, is it politics or an audition for the next action movie? "Coming this summer: Takaichi Unchained!" Who knew charisma was just a tough stance on China and a friendship with Trump?

Chris Rock: Ben Gvir's out here telling the Attorney General, "I heard you, but your advice ain't getting accepted!" Man, that sounds like the world’s worst therapy session! It's like someone sitting on a couch saying, “Doc, I hear you, but I’m gonna keep doing me!” That’s like getting a financial advisor who says, “Invest in stocks!” and you reply, “Nah, I’m gonna keep buying lottery tickets instead—way more exciting!” Meanwhile, we’ve got people questioning, “Is there really a crisis with the ultra-Orthodox?” Are you kidding me? No crisis? The only crisis is the denial! In the same room with the Attorney General, holding a meeting where no one’s taking notes but everyone’s taking shots. This is a circus without a tent, folks!

**Jerry Seinfeld**: You ever notice how they say the attack on religious Zionism is as ugly as it is foolish? It’s like, isn’t that the default state for all arguments? I mean, show me an argument that isn’t ugly and foolish! You could argue, “Hey, what color should we paint the fence?” and somehow it turns into a shouting match about the state of the universe. And here we are, storming over arrangements in yeshivas like we’re planning a wedding—only instead of the bouquet toss, we’re throwing verbal haymakers about who’s got the better interpretation of the divine!

Mitch Hedberg: I heard there’s a smuggler who got caught with 42 guns and 729 rounds of ammo. That’s like showing up to a potluck with a full buffet and shouting, “Who invited all this firepower? I just wanted to bring a salad!” I mean, what’s next? A border guard pulling over a guy because he’s transporting five American transport planes? “Sir, this isn’t a game of Monopoly!”

Chris Rock: You ever notice that a US military plane is flying from Texas to Tel Aviv? I mean, is this a military mission or a round trip for the world's most expensive barbecue? They’re hauling billions in equipment while most of us can barely afford a plane ticket for a vacation! But here’s the kicker—while they're flying to save the world, folks in Tehran are out there with signs in the square like, “Here’s the target!” It’s like they turned a conflict zone into a hipster art exhibit! Who knew war had a better marketing strategy than most startup companies? They’re treating a missile rain like it’s a bad weather forecast— “Don’t worry, folks, just a little turbulence and hopefully this area stays green!” It’s a mess, man, real chaotic energy!

Lewis Black: Can you believe the Israeli cabinet trying to deepen land annexation in the West Bank? It’s like watching a toddler jog with scissors—except instead of a band-aid, we're just bracing for an international incident! They’re calling their decisions "null and void," which is ironic because the last time I heard “null and void,” it was my subscription to cable after my last argument with the customer service rep! Look, if I had a dollar for every time a government made a mess of things, I could probably fund a sensible solution—oh wait, I already do, it’s called my tax bill!

Suzy Izzard: Imagine Major General Mousavi standing over a giant chessboard while declaring, "We're ready for a long-term war!" and all I can think is, what are they playing, checkers with real aggression? It’s like reading in the history books that while the Silk Road was bustling with trade and spice, somewhere out there, oil was just sitting on the sidelines, sulking because it didn’t get the memo that innovation was the real prize! I mean, when you hear about a “hidden war” against industrialization, do you picture giant oil barrels sneaking around in trench coats? "Psst! Not here, just a big barrel of crude trying to learn polymer chemistry—don’t tell the sanctions!" Who knew the biggest competition was a bunch of barrels trying to dress up as value-added products?

Mitch Hedberg: If Iran's secretly transferring launchers to make them hard to destroy, I guess their launchers are like my old gym membership—impossible to find and only come with a lot of hidden fees. I’d also like to know when the eastern part of the country started playing hide-and-seek. Sounds like the world could use some more playful diplomacy, or at least a good game of tag—which, ironically, is what I'm always trying to avoid at the gym.

Jerry Seinfeld: Isn’t it funny how in Ofakim, you can get a knock-down, drag-out street fight going on over something as simple as, I don't know, which way the wind is blowing? I mean, when did the streets become the stage for Bedouin brawls? You think they’d been waiting for the right moment to settle disputes, but instead, they just took it to the pavement like, “Why argue civilly when we can settle this with a few right hooks?!” It’s like they skipped conflict resolution classes and went right to the interpretive dance of punches. Who teaches these guys etiquette? “Excuse me, is this a public space or a boxing ring?” It’s all so absurd, yet here we are, just trying to find some peace in our neighborhoods!

Chris Rock: You see these headlines? Jordan condemning Israel for deepening settlements like it’s not the pot calling the kettle black! It’s like watching two broke friends fighting over who can steal more from the other—“Hey man, you can’t claim that parking spot when you don’t even own a car!” And while you got Khaled Mashal out here talking about “more attacks are coming” like he’s the world’s worst movie billboard—bro, it’s not a sequel we’re waiting for! It’s like he’s running the most dysfunctional Hollywood studio. How about a rom-com about peace, fellas? But no, they’re out here casting for action movies while we can’t even get a buddy cop flick!

Lewis Black: So I read that families from Majdal Shams are suing Hezbollah for 80 million shekels over a children's disaster, and I couldn't help but think, "Is suing people the new form of modern parenting?" I mean, why bother with 'talking it out' when you can just drop the hammer and demand more cash than most small countries have for a mess that sounds like it was pulled straight from the script of a bad action movie?! I can just picture Hezbollah in their headquarters: "What do you mean they're suing us? We thought we were just throwing a birthday party!" The whole thing is like watching two toddlers arguing over a toy while throwing Monopoly money at each other—except this time, it’s real lives and real money, and the adults are nowhere to be seen!

Sarah Silverman: Isn’t it funny how the Reiwa Shinsengumi party in Japan—a group that lost all their seats because they couldn’t figure out how to win a single vote—was once the go-to option for pro-Palestinian protests? I mean, if you’re going to fight for a cause, at least pick one that has support, right? It’s like trying to save the whales… in a kiddie pool. What’s next? "Hey, folks, let’s throw a rager for the environmentalists at a landfill! I hear they’re really keen on recycling their political hopes!"

**Sarah Silverman:** So, an Arab woman is running in the Democratic primaries, promising to work for an Arab-Jewish partnership. Isn’t it sweet? It’s like she’s throwing a party to celebrate diversity and hoping the only thing that gets blown up are the balloons. Meanwhile, over in Syria, we’ve got kids released from ISIS camps—now dubbed “Caliphate Cubs.” Apparently, the new kids’ meal this year comes with a toy gun and a side of existential dread. Talk about your happy meal on the go!

Lewis Black: Can we talk about the Reiwa Shinsengumi party in Japan? They were out there waving pro-China and pro-Palestinian flags like it was a summer sale at a clearance rack! And they lost all nine of their seats! Nine! That's not a party; that's a community potluck gone horribly wrong! How do you organize protests against Israel and still manage to get outdone by a narcoleptic sloth in a local election? I mean, who needs enemies when your political strategy is worse than a cat video on mute? They’ve gone from parliamentary representation to chasing down a prayer for just one measly seat! Maybe next time, they'll try running a campaign based on common sense—oh wait, that would be a first!

Lewis Black: You know, it's astonishing what our leaders prioritize these days. I mean, ultra-Orthodox Knesset members meet with the legal advisor about the conscription law for five hours! Five hours! Meanwhile, a massive brawl breaks out in Ofakim, and the police respond like it's an invitation to a tea party! It's like they’re saying, “Ladies and gentlemen, our priorities are now on par with trying to decide which flavor of ice cream pairs best with chaos!” Who needs law and order when you can just slap a bunch of suits around the table and call it diplomacy? Only in this world do we investigate a fistfight while drafting laws that are about as popular as a root canal!

Jerry Seinfeld: Isn’t it strange how Iran announces they're closing airspace over a missile base? I mean, is that really the kind of thing you want to be publicizing? It's like saying, "Hey everyone, we're about to paint the house, so please ignore all the open cans of paint and ladders in the driveway!" Who are they expecting to be up there, a flock of pigeons with a vendetta? Meanwhile, over in Thailand, they’ve got a Prime Minister who won with a whopping 192 seats. That’s not an election, that’s a family reunion! You think they just kept counting until someone finally said, “Alright, that’s enough hugging; let’s take a vote and get some hot dogs!”

**Eddie Izzard**: So, in Iran, they've issued a NOTAM—like a no-fly list for missiles, right? You know the kind, "Hey, missiles! This is a restricted zone, mind your manners—no launching unless you're invited to the birthday party!" Meanwhile, somewhere in Jadida Makr, a house has just been mistaken for a piñata! A fragmentation grenade? Really? It’s like turning your house into a game show set—"Will it blend?" but instead, it just leaves you with a slightly ruined backyard and no birthday cake. Imagine the house saying, “Well, I was just trying to hold it together for the neighborhood watch! Who invited chaos to my front lawn?” It’s as if missiles and grenades have become the hot new trend in home decoration—forget Feng Shui, just launch a grenade and call it industrial chic!

**Eddie Izzard:** Imagine a Russian spokesperson claiming Epstein is just a “small snowflake on a huge iceberg.” It’s as if an icecap was slowly saying, “You’ve seen my tip, but darling, the rest of me is a frozen solid mass of conspiracy. Meanwhile, some guy in Beit Shemesh is just trying to put out a fire in a residential building, and I can’t help but wonder: what’s more dangerous, a conspiracy of elites or a rogue toaster at a brunch party? Because both seem to serve up nothing but burnt toast! And over in Iran, a Nobel laureate is being sentenced to seven years in prison—talk about an overreaction! I mean, is winning a Peace Prize supposed to come with the fine print: ‘May result in extensive vacations in prison’? You see, when history meets the absurd, everyone ends up in either a tiny, existential existentialist quandary or just left waiting for the kettle to boil amidst the chaos of global toast!

**Chris Rock**: Man, did you hear about this fire on Nahal Kishon Street in Beit Shemesh? No casualties! I mean, that's great news, but in a world where people are burning their dinners and calling it a "cooking disaster," why we celebrating that people can't manage a candle? It's like saying, "Hey, at least nobody’s winning a Darwin Award today!" Come on, if you can’t handle a pot on the stove, you need more than a fire extinguisher - you need a fire drill! It’s a kitchen, not a reality TV show!

Lewis Black: So, the Iranian consulate in Basra issues a fiery warning that any attack from the U.S. or Israel will lead to an "all-out war." Yeah, nothing says peace like a public statement that sounds like a toddler declaring a tantrum! Meanwhile, Ali Larijani is getting ready to book a trip to Oman—if, and I quote, "no military event occurs by next week." I mean, how absurd is that? It’s like saying, “I’ll be at the picnic unless it rains napalm!” And, of course, just when you think these guys can't get any more ridiculous, we’ve got Qatar launching a conference to fight terrorism financing. That’s right, folks! Organizing a meeting about financing terrorism, because clearly the best way to solve a problem is to discuss it over sandwiches and maybe a PowerPoint! What happened to common sense? These people are like a circus, but instead of clowns, we’ve got politicians juggling bombs!

Jerry Seinfeld: You ever notice how a family can escape Tehran with nothing but the clothes on their backs and then refuse a reception center? I mean, this is like the ultimate "I don't need your charity" move. It’s one thing to flee a regime, but now they’re turning down free food and shelter? What’s the etiquette here? Are we supposed to applaud or just assume they brought their own hummus? I'm starting to think that sometimes people just like their challenges—"Oh, a reception center? No thanks! We're going to do this the hard way, and we’ll manage without your extra pillows!"

**Lewis Black**: Can we talk about the absurdity of the Qatari money deal with Gaza? It's like a bad game of Monopoly where the only property being bought is “International Political Hot Potato.” They give Hamas cash to calm things down—cash! What’s next, a fruit basket for the angry neighbor? “Listen, we know you’ve been throwing rocks, so here’s a nice assortment of organic apples and a check for ten million—just try to keep it down over there!” This is not problem-solving; it’s like saying, "You can rent my anger for a monthly fee!" Who thought paying off hostility would ever be a viable solution? It’s like a global edition of “You don’t have to go home, but you can’t stay here!” but with a side of economic madness.

Lewis Black: Oh, fantastic! Iran is pumping out 300 ballistic missiles a month. It's like they’ve got a subwoofer in the factory blasting “Missile Maker’s Greatest Hits” while everyone else is trying to figure out how to keep the lights on and the coffee hot! Meanwhile, here we are, worried about whether our coffee makers are going to work long enough to stop us from showing up to work in our pajamas! I mean, which one of those seems like the bigger problem, folks? They’re over there missile-ing like they’re playing whack-a-mole, and we’re here debating whether to bring our eco-friendly reusable cup to the coffee shop! This isn’t just absurd; it’s a cosmic joke where we’re all the punchline!

**Lewis Black**: Can we talk about the Qatari contributions to Gaza, the money that’s apparently flowing in suitcases like it's some twisted version of Santa’s workshop? I mean, how ridiculous is it that we're relying on cash-filled luggage to maintain peace? It’s like if you went to your boss asking for a raise and instead of a check, they gave you a duffel bag of Monopoly money! Are politicians so out of touch that they think this is how you solve a problem? “Hey, let’s just keep giving money to Hamas so they chill out!” It’s like trying to calm a wild dog with steak—sure, they’re nice for a minute, but the moment you turn your back, guess what? You've got no arm left!

Chris Rock: You ever notice how we got a Somali mayor telling Americans what it means to be American? Now listen, I’m all for immigrants speaking up, but it’s like a guy with no credit telling you how to buy a house! America’s out here going crazy, “We’re losing our Americanness!” Baby, half of us don't even know what that means anymore! We got people in this country who think “real American” is just short for “owns a gun and complains about water!” It’s wild! You can’t come from nowhere and lecture me about what’s real, especially when America’s looking like a two-week-old salad—wobbly and, quite frankly, going bad!

Mitch Hedberg: I once heard Naftali Bennett call Netanyahu a “weak-willed creature.” That’s funny because in politics, you can be led around by your own whims without even a leash. It's like a hamster running on a wheel, convinced it's going somewhere, while the wheel is just a Qatari cash conveyor belt. They say money talks, but in this case, it just whispers sweet nothings while running in circles.

**Eddie Izzard:** Imagine the cash-stuffed suitcases rolling into Gaza, like a bizarre episode of 'Cribs: Diplomat Edition.' You've got piles of money meant to calm Hamas, which is like handing a toddler a cookie to stop them from throwing a tantrum—sure, it works for a minute, but next thing you know, they start a very expensive game of dodgeball with the international community! And you have to wonder, did Netanyahu sit there, looking at the money, and think, “Well, this is how we negotiate peace in the 21st century—big bags of cash and the occasional angry shout. I should really start wrapping my birthday presents this way!” Because honestly, at this rate, the next Middle Eastern peace summit might just involve Monopoly money and a pie-eating contest to settle disputes!
Mitch Hedberg: Arrests in Ramallah sound like an intense game of hide and seek, but with less hiding and more seeking out warrants—or as I like to call it, 'warranted fun'.

Mitch Hedberg: You know, Turkey and Egypt signed a weapons deal worth $350 million, which is great—because nothing says “peace” quite like buying artillery shells. Meanwhile, in a completely different universe, they’re blocking the Ayalon lanes for "work at the Peace Interchange." I guess if you can’t drive to war, you might as well sit in traffic and contemplate the existential crisis of a paperclip.

Sarah Silverman: You know, I was reading about this motorcyclist who got seriously injured on Highway 4, and it got me thinking—what's the deal with those reckless drivers? I mean, if you're gonna risk your life flying down the highway, at least have the decency to take out a speed limit sign or a fruit stand. I mean, come on. It’s not like they put those signs there for your amusement! It's like they want you to turn “Highway to Hell” into an actual road trip. You’ve got to wonder if that was the original plan—like, "Hey, let’s create a highway that leads right to the ER!"

**Chris Rock:** So Egypt's planning a war and Turkey's like, "Y'all know who our enemy is? Israel!" I’m just sitting here thinking, if these folks put as much energy into building schools and hospitals as they do planning a full-on family reunion of chaos, we'd be solving problems instead of creating them! It’s the Sunni crew versus the Shiite squad, and here I am just trying to figure out how to get a decent falafel without geopolitics getting involved. I mean, come on! Ain't nobody got time for a global jihad when you can’t even get agreement on the best way to deep-fry chickpeas!

Chris Rock: You know what's wild? Qatar's been giving money to Gaza like it's their part-time job—$15 million here, $30 million there, and I'm over here just trying to get my tax refund! I mean, they’re sliding cash in like, “Here’s a hundred bucks for the kids, and oh, by the way, here's ten million for Hamas—just a little something to keep the peace!” It's like trying to pay off your neighbor to stop playing loud music at 2 AM—“Hey man, here’s a tenner, can you chill with the bass?” But they’re not chilling! They’re building bombs like they're playing a video game! You ever seen a neighborhood budget where you pay for the backyard barbecue and the fireworks show? That's not a civic duty, that’s a horror movie waiting to happen!

**Jerry Seinfeld**: What’s the deal with these annual Qatari contributions to Gaza? Every year it’s like a bad sitcom plot that just won’t end. You have a mix of politicians treating humanitarian aid like a recurring subscription service, renewing it like it’s Netflix! “Hey, Israel, we’ve got the latest season of Qatari cash coming in. Will it be the same formula as last year? Sure! We’ll just change the channel name! Can’t wait for the cliffhanger!" It's like everyone is hoping for “less drama” but ends up with “no budget for the sequel!”

Lewis Black: So Iran’s apparently moving its ballistic missiles to the east to make them harder to target. Really? This is where we are now? They're playing missile hide-and-seek, while the rest of us are stuck in a game of political charades! I mean, how incompetent do you have to be to think, “Hey, if we just shuffle a few missiles around like we’re rearranging furniture, no one will even notice!” What’s next? Are they going to start wrapping them in bubble wrap and tossing them into the east like it’s some sort of twisted gift exchange? This isn't just absurd; it’s enough to make you want to scream!

Eddie Izzard: Imagine a meeting between Turkey and Egypt where, instead of deepening security cooperation with their $350 million weapons deal, they ended up arguing over who makes a better cup of coffee. You've got Erdogan passionately advocating for his espresso machine, citing historical battles of caffeine throughout the Byzantine Empire, while the Egyptian negotiator is nodding along, sipping a sweetened hibiscus tea, saying, "Listen, we can have a Turkish delight of artillery systems, but if I can’t get a decent brew for my morning meeting, what’s the point? A short-range defense system won't protect my taste buds!”

Lewis Black: You know what's absolutely insane? We're throwing millions of dollars into Gaza to keep peace—like it's some sort of cash-tendered truce! I mean, what’s next? A reality TV show called “Keeping Up with the Cash Flow”? “Tonight on a very special episode: Benjamin tries to give money to Hamas while dodging incoming rockets!” It’s like running a charity bingo game where everyone’s armed and the only prize is *more chaos*! I’m just saying, if we treated politics like my grandma's soup recipe, maybe we wouldn’t be so busy simmering in this boiling pot of lunacy!
